titleStmt.title: The truest, most happy, and joyfull newes that ever came from Ireland: being sent over in a letter, and read in the honourable House of Common, Februarie 29. 1641. Relating the renowned victory of the Protestant party, in repelling the rebels from Dublin, under the commands of the Earl of Ormond, Sir Charles Coot, and Sir Simon Harcourt. With the noble service of Captain Thomas Stenvile, near to the town of Trohedagh. As also, the apprehension of Mac Brian, Con Magenis at Care, Rory Magwire at the town of Clogham, and others who are principall conspirators, and actors in the rebellion. The three commanders afore-mentioned having (according to the late proclamation set forth by the Lord Justices of Dublin) six hundred pounds a man for the apprehension of those three rebels.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 6 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 4 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: The truest, most happy, and joyfull newes that ever came from Ireland: being sent over in a letter, and read in the honourable House of Common, Februarie 29. 1641. Relating the renowned victory of the Protestant party, in repelling the rebels from Dublin, under the commands of the Earl of Ormond, Sir Charles Coot, and Sir Simon Harcourt. With the noble service of Captain Thomas Stenvile, near to the town of Trohedagh. As also, the apprehension of Mac Brian, Con Magenis at Care, Rory Magwire at the town of Clogham, and others who are principall conspirators, and actors in the rebellion. The three commanders afore-mentioned having (according to the late proclamation set forth by the Lord Justices of Dublin) six hundred pounds a man for the apprehension of those three rebels.

notesStmt.note: The comma following "Conspirators" appears to have been inverted.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The True≈øt, mo≈øt happy, and joyfull NEWES THAT EVER CAME FROM IRELAND: BEING SENT OVER IN A LETTER, and read in the Honourable Hou≈øe of Common, Februarie 29. 1641.

Relating the renowned Victory of the Prote≈øtant Party, in Repelling the Rebels from Dublin, under the Commands of the Earl of Ormond, Sir Charles Coot, and Sir Simon Harcourt. With the Noble Service of Captain Thomas Stenvile, near to the Town of Trohedagh.
As al≈øo, the Apprehen≈øion of MacBrian, Con Magenis at Care, Rory Magwire at the Town of Clogham, and others who are principall Con≈øpirators and Actors in the Rebellion.
The three Commanders afore-mentioned having (according to the late Proclamation ≈øet forth by the Lord Ju≈øtices of Dublin) ≈øix hundred pounds a man for the Apprehen≈øion of tho≈øe three Rebels.
Mar. 3. London. Printed for William Reynor. 1641.

div.head: THE TRUEST, MOST Happie, and Jovfull Newes, that ever came from IRELAND.
div.p:
LOng have tyrannicall in≈øolencie of the Rebels in Ireland exalted over the liberties, lives, and Con≈øciences of the Prote≈øtants: and hath hitherto continued ≈øo cruell, bloudy, and inhumane, that it ≈øupifies almo≈øt amaze ment it ≈øelf: and withall, hath endangered the hazard of the Kingdome, But although they have triumphed thus in the continuation of their barbarous inhumanity. Yet the All-≈øeeing eye of the Almighty, who≈øe impartiall Ju≈øtice will not permit nefarious deeds to ≈øleep in impunity, the omnipotency (I ≈øay) of the ≈øame eye hath frowned upon the Rebellious proceedings of tho≈øe ≈øavage
mi≈øcreants, which cau≈øeth no onely alacrity in the hearts of all, but al≈øo to heaven, for ≈øo ju≈øt an overthrow. Their repul≈øe was thus, as ≈øhall be ≈øub≈øequently declared.

The Citie of Dublin was ≈øuppo≈øed to have bin in great perill, being dangerou≈øly invironed, and begirt with the enemy both by Sea, and Land: Yea, moreover there were divers Letters ≈øent from We≈øtche≈øter, directed to the Hou≈øe of Commons, and read; who≈øe meaning did ≈øtrengthen the former ≈øu≈øpitiou: for they did intimate that Dublin was ≈øo circumvolved with the enemy, that it was almo≈øt thought to be de≈øtitute ef Relief: Then it was forthwith Ordered by the Hou≈øe, that pre≈øent Aid ≈øhould be immediately rai≈øed, and ≈øent thither with great expedition, for fear if they ≈øhould procra≈øtinate the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, any danger might en≈øue,

Hereupon the Commi≈ø≈øion to pre≈ø≈øe (both for Land and Sea-men) did i≈ø≈øue
forthwith to His Maje≈øties Officers. But in the mean time the Prote≈øtants gathered a head together, and unanimou≈øly con≈øulted to have a skirmi≈øh with the Rebels, and ≈øo to relieve the City of Dublin.

The Earl of Ormond, Sir Charles Coot, and Sir Simon Harcourt mu≈øtred up their forces, and marched couragiou≈øly again≈øt them: whereupon at their fir≈øt fir≈øt On≈øet, there was a hot fray on both ≈øides, till at length Captain Thomas Stanvile came with three hundred men afre≈øh, and then they ≈ølew many of the Rebels, and made them recant, ≈øome fled, others hid them≈øelves: but ≈øtill they followed them, ≈ølaying a great number, rooting them from one Town to another: and ≈øo they rook Mac Brian Pri≈øoner, and driving them ≈øtill forward, they took Con Magenis at Care, and at the Town of Clogham they took Kory Magwire all Pri≈øoners, and committed them to the Ca≈øtle in Dublin.

And there was (according to the „Äà‚óä„Äâ Proclamation ≈øet forth by the Lord Ju≈øtices of Dublin g ‚Ä¢ ven to all ingenerall both Engli≈øh and Iri≈øh) given to tho≈øe Commanders that apprehended tho≈øe three ≈øix hundred pounds a man. So that hereby Dublin is made free at this pre≈øent from any enemy, to the great comfort and con≈øolation of tho≈øe worthy Members that are now Fathers of our Country.

We hope likewi≈øe, that by the auxiliary a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Almighty God, that when our King and Parliament ≈øhall be graciou≈øly plea≈øed to ≈øend more aid thither, that we ≈øhall ≈øubdue the barbarous rage of tho≈øe Rebels with facility. In the mean time, we have ju≈øt cau≈øe to pray for the propitious ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe, who are there already arrived: that God would ≈øo animate them with valour and courage, that they may undantedly ≈øtand for the defence of his holy Go≈øpell, and propagation of his divine Name: That they be ≈øo ≈øtrongly
armed with the true faith of Chri≈øt, that withall they ≈øhould become more propen≈øe, and ready to oppo≈øe all tho≈øe enemies, that ≈øhall dare ‚Ä¢ r pre≈øume to derogate the lea≈øt title therefrom. God grant that all our battles may prove as fortunate, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øive as this hath, and then we doubt not but we ≈øhall become tr ly victorious: That the Prote≈øtant Religion do not thus initiate, and be fir≈øt a≈øcribed with the Characters of blood: That the pro≈øperous ≈øecuritie of the Briti≈øh Nation, be not overwhelmed with the turbulent barbari≈øm of tho≈øe Wolvi≈øh Rebels. That the heart of our gracious Soveraign may be con≈øolated with more active alacritie: That the heaven-guided Parliament may be likewi≈øe comforted and not to receive ≈øuch ≈øtrange ob≈øtacles, and dangerous ob≈øtructions to their quotidian proceedings: That la≈øtly, the honour of God may be advanced to the great ≈øecurity of the Realm.
